awd_titl_txt: CRII: Algorithms and Methodologies for Real-Time Decision-Making of Mission-Critical Structures Experiencing High-Rate Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on investigations into methodologies to enable real-time decision-making for mission-critical structural systems experiencing high-rate dynamics. Examples of mission-critical structures that experience high-rate dynamics include hypersonic vehicles, space crafts, ballistics packages, and active blast mitigation. Enabling real-time decision-making for these structures increases mission success rates by enhancing the structure's survivability, providing on-time guidance corrections, and adopting the mission goals/outcome to changing conditions. Additionally, the methodologies developed by this project increase the robustness, safety, and commercial viability of structures operating in extreme dynamic environments. The development of algorithms and methodologies for structures experiencing high-rate dynamics serves the national interest and fulfills the NSF's mission:  to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare; or to secure the national defense.  This project provides research experience and mentors a diverse and inclusive group of students, and introduces a graduate level class on surrogate modeling of complex systems.

A structural system operating in a high-rate dynamic environment can experience sudden and unmodeled plastic deformation of the structure that may further lead to damaged electronics, sensors, and/or delicate payloads. This research focuses on enabling a real-time decision-making module to take corrective actions. To achieve this goal, a parallelization framework is developed that enables a structural system to be decomposed into its constituent components where each component can be monitored, modeled, and extrapolated into the future. Once the degradation trajectories for each component have been estimated, they are recombined into a single system-level model to be used for real-time decision making.  The project is organized into two research thrusts and one experimental design challenge. Thrust 1 investigates surrogate modeling techniques with the goal of developing component-level models that can converge within the required time constraints. These surrogate models use data obtained from dense sensor networks to generate data-driven damage-sensitive features that can be used as the degradation parameters for component-level prognostics. Thrust 2 explores and formulates methodologies for real-time component-level prognostics. These component-level predictions are then recombined into a single structural model that is used to develop potential corrective actions. Lastly, the experimental design challenge validates the developed algorithms and methodologies using a high-rate dynamic test bench.

This project is jointly funded by Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (OAC) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

por.por_cntn:
The project and associated supplement for a Research Experience for Undergraduates has been completed.

The project developed algorithms and methodologies for the real-time model updating of structures experiencing high-rate dynamics. The project showed that the direct use of finite element models solved in the frequency domain does not meet the stringent timing constraints demanded by high-rate dynamics. In particular, the time required to solve the generalized eigenvalue problem within the finite element analysis solution was too time-consuming. To circumvent this issue, the local eigenvalue modification procedure was investigated by an M.S. student to reduce the computational load and published as a thesis. Later, a Ph.D. student developed a real-time ?divide and conquer'' solver for the local eigenvalue modification procedure and showed that the local eigenvalue modification procedure offers a tremendous speedup in terms of computation time. The most recent work shows a 125 times speedup for a finite element model with 250 nodes when compared to the generalized eigenvalue problem. This portion of the project contributed to 1 M.S. thesis and two ongoing Ph.D. dissertations for three NSF-underrepresented students in STEM.

A key challenge in monitoring structures operating in high-rate dynamic environments is that time-series-based measurements made with vibration-based sensors take time to fully decompose the change in dynamics of a structure that is subjected to damage or impact. To allow for the direct detection of impacts, and the incorporation of structure state into the models, this project investigated large-area sensors for damage impact detection. These sensors will enable direct knowledge of impacts to be integrated into real-time model updating schemes moving forward. This work experimentally and numerically demonstrated that large-area sensors, such as those used in a network configuration, could be used to directly detect, localize, and quantify impact damage on a structure. This portion of the project contributed to an ongoing Ph.D. dissertation for an NSF-underrepresented student in STEM.

The project funded the development of a testbed for the controlled generation of simulated high-rate dynamic data. Through two senior design projects (involving 8 undergrads), the testbed was developed. The testbed was used to investigate the potential for real-time model updating for a structure under impact and fatigue damage. This testbed, along with the data acquisition systems funded through this project, has been vital in developing preliminary data for future proposals related to model updating for structures. An undergraduate student who worked on the development of the project for their senior design stayed at the University of South Carolina to do an M.S. in Mechanical Engineering. They subsequently were awarded a graduate student fellowship by the United States Navy to work as a civilian engineer within the Navy after graduation, where they currently are at the conclusion of this project. This portion of the project contributed to an MS thesis for one student and undergraduate design experience for 8 undergraduate students.

Work undertaken as part of this project showed that more data is needed to test and validate the model updating techniques being developed. However, time-series experimental data for structures experiencing high-rate dynamic events are expensive to obtain. Moreover, it is computationally prohibitive to use physics-based models, such as finite element analysis, to generate the needed amount of data. Therefore, the project team investigated the use of generative artificial intelligence (AI) to generate simulated data. The project team developed a method to synthesize new data by leveraging existing but expensive (time and resource) experimental data using Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN). The methodology for developing this data will be used in the future for validating real-time model updating techniques for structures operating in high-rate dynamic scenarios. This portion of the project contributed to an ongoing Ph.D. dissertation for an NSF-underrepresented student in STEM.

Educational outcomes at the University of South Carolina included the involvement of two paid undergraduate students through a ?Research Experience for Undergraduate? supplement award. These students (one NSF-underrepresented student) demonstrated the viability of using smart structures for detecting impact and quantifying the orientation (direction of travel) of the impactor. The project facilitated the development of various shock and vibration data sets that have been integrated into the undergraduate curriculum within mechanical engineering and made freely available through various open-source projects and textbooks. The project introduced graduate students to surrogate modeling of complex systems.

Overall, the project provided research experience and mentored a diverse and inclusive group of students. The project?s development of algorithms and methodologies for structures experiencing high-rate dynamics served the national interest and fulfills the NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; or to secure the national defense. 

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2023
Modified by: Austin Downey
